comment.author: 90821451@N00
comment._content: The stories that ship could tell!

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: indeed...  she survived WWI, served at Jutland firing 62 large shells and receiving no hits.  She was involved in multiple collisions but no ships were sunk.  The Bellerophon class came after the Dreadnought and was an improvement on her.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: HMS Bellerophon was a dreadnought of the Royal Navy. She was the lead ship of the Bellerophon class, and the fourth Royal Navy vessel to bear the name of the mythic Greek hero. Built at the Royal Dockyard in Portsmouth and completed in 1909, Bellerophon first joined the 1st Battle Squadron and then upon the outbreak of war joined the 4th Battle Squadron where she remained until 1919. She was present at the Battle of Jutland where she fired sixty-two 12 inch rounds and received no damage. With the end of the war she was placed in the Reserve Fleet and sold for scrap in 1921 before being taken to the breakers two years later.
